channel.title: R Markdown on Smart Analytics for Big Data
channel.description: Recent content in R Markdown on Smart Analytics for Big Data

item.title: Graphics with R
item.description: Grammar of ggplot2() Start example df <- data.frame(x=1:15, y=1:15) ggplot(df, aes(x,y)) + geom_point() + labs( title= "Plot example", subtitle = "Subtitled", x="x-values", y = "y-values" ) + theme(panel.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color= "grey50")) Grammar of graphic: ggplot The ggplot2 package is loaded to access the ggplot() function. The graph is created by stacking together several short phrases, each describing an aspect of the graphic. With ggplot, the data need need not to be reshaped for each type of graphical representation (boxplot, histogram, scatter,â€¦).

item.title: Introduction to Data Vizualisation
item.description: Application Designing a visualization The use of visualization is pervasive in the scientific production and communication: explanatory diagrams, graphs describing statistics, new experimental data plotted against theoretical expectations, etc. In each case, the author of the visualization tries to lead readers to a specific point of view, by emphasizing some aspects of the data while toning down other aspects. Results may be informative, decisive or misleading. Can you apply the design principles we talked about in class?

item.title: Introduction to Reproducible Analysis
item.description: Reproducible Analysis Typical data analysis workflow looks like this: collect data put it in a file or spreadsheet or database run some analyses, written in various scripts, perhaps saving some intermediate results along the way or maybe always working on the raw data. create some plots or tables of relevant summaries of the data, and then go and write a report about the results in a text editor or word processor.

item.title: Introductory Cases Studies
item.description: Case Study Work group: By group of 5 to 6 students: you will explore one of the following links you will search for the data type, qualification, etc you will question the workflow supporting the website you will question the interpretation, the vizualisation of the results, its strengths and weaknesses you will present your result using an RMarkdown presentation (HTML IoSlides or Beamer) - No more than 4 slides First: names, title, link as subtitle Second: survey of the data elements Third: workflow 1 Fourth: critical analysis Cases - links CS0 - Mobility and Covid19 https://ivtmobis.

item.title: Lessons index
item.description: This is the website of the Lesson Smart Analytics for Big Data taught at Grenoble INP Industrial Engineering and Management School & UGA. Lessons list in reverse order Seventh Lesson - 19/11/2020 - 9:30 - 12:30 and 13:30 - 15:00 Material for the Seventh Lesson Sixth Lesson - 12/11/2020 - 9:30 - 12:30 Material for the Sixth Lesson Fifth Lesson - 05/11/2020 - 8:00 - 12:30 Material for the Fifth Lesson
